knowledge: Heart Attack Heart Attack A heart attack occurs when the flow of blood to the heart is blocked, most often by a build-up of fat, cholesterol and other substances, which form a plaque in the arteries that feed the heart (coronary arteries). The interrupted blood flow can damage or destroy part of the heart muscle.  The most common symptom of a heart attack is chest pain, usually described as crushing, squeezing, pressing, heavy, or full. The pain may spread to the shoulders, neck, arms, jaw, or back, and may also feel like indigestion. Other possible symptoms include shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, lightheadedness, sweating, and anxiety.  Risk factors for heart attacks include smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, obesity, lack of physical activity, and family history of heart disease. Heart Attack Heart Attack
response: A heart attack occurs when the flow of blood to the heart is blocked by a build-up of fat, cholesterol and other substances, which form a plaque in the arteries that feed the heart (coronary arteries).
